Reidemeister 3 Move¶

# Prerequisites: 1. The SGD has at least one face whose 3 vertices are crossings. 2. The candidate face has at least one edge that pass completely under or over the other two edges.

# Algorithm: 1. Identify the candidate face for the R3 move. - If there is more than one face that satisfies the R3 prerequisites, then choose one (TODO Implement choosing logic).

2. Identify the candidate edge for the R3 move. - If the chosen face as more than one edge that passes completely under or over the other two edges, choose one (TODO Implement choosing logic).

3. Label each vertex and edge of the candidate face. - The R3 moves one edge across its opposing vertex. - The chosen edge will be called the “moving” or “opposite” edge since it will move across the opposing vertex. - The vertex opposing the moving edge will be called the “keep” crossing since it will remain in place. - The two edges adjacent to the keep crossing will be called “common” edges (as opposed to the opposing edge). - The two other crossings will be called “remove” crossings since moving the opposite edge will remove these crossings (and introduce two new crossings on the other side of the keep crossing).

4. Identify how edge and crossing indices will change by the R3 move. - The moving edge intersects with two keep crossing edges. The R3 move will cause it to intersect the opposite two edges (i… ). - When we remove the two remove crossings, two edges represent the moving edge and will be moved by the R3 move. The other two edges must spliced together. - …

5. Perform the R3 move. - Delete the two edges that do not move. - Connect … - Shift the two move crossings - Add new edges… -

First, we will define the knot before performing the R3.

Example Test Function¶
 1
 2
 3def test_does_not_have_r3():
 4    # TODO: Implement
 5    pass
 6
 7
 8def test_has_r3(two_unknots_1):
 9    # Conventions _1, _2 follow clockwise ordering.
10
11    r3_moves = available_r3_moves(two_unknots_1)
12    assert len(r3_moves) == 8
13
14    # Face c1, c2, c3 has 2 possible R3 moves
15    r3_1 = {'stationary_crossing': 'c1',
16            'stationary_edge_1': 'e1',
17            'stationary_edge_2': 'e2',
18            'moving_crossing_1': 'c2',
19            'moving_crossing_2': 'c3',
20            'moving_edge': 'e6'}
21
22    r3_2 = {'stationary_crossing': 'c2',
23            'stationary_edge_1': 'e6',
24            'stationary_edge_2': 'e1',
25            'moving_crossing_1': 'c3',
26            'moving_crossing_2': 'c1',
27            'moving_edge': 'e2'}
28
29    assert r3_1 in r3_moves
30    assert r3_2 in r3_moves
31
32    # Face c1, c3, c4 has 2 possible R3 moves
33    r3_3 = {'stationary_crossing': 'c1',
34            'stationary_edge_1': 'e2',
35            'stationary_edge_2': 'e3',
36            'moving_crossing_1': 'c3',
37            'moving_crossing_2': 'c4',
38            'moving_edge': 'e7'}
39
40    r3_4 = {'stationary_crossing': 'c4',
41            'stationary_edge_1': 'e3',
42            'stationary_edge_2': 'e7',
43            'moving_crossing_1': 'c1',
44            'moving_crossing_2': 'c3',
45            'moving_edge': 'e2'}
46
47    assert r3_3 in r3_moves

Then we will define the ground truth of the R3 move.

Example Test Function¶
 1    # Face c1, c4, c5 has 2 possible R3 moves
 2    r3_5 = {'stationary_crossing': 'c1',
 3            'stationary_edge_1': 'e3',
 4            'stationary_edge_2': 'e4',
 5            'moving_crossing_1': 'c4',
 6            'moving_crossing_2': 'c5',
 7            'moving_edge': 'e8'}
 8
 9    r3_6 = {'stationary_crossing': 'c4',
10            'stationary_edge_1': 'e8',
11            'stationary_edge_2': 'e3',
12            'moving_crossing_1': 'c5',
13            'moving_crossing_2': 'c1',
14            'moving_edge': 'e4'}
15
16    assert r3_5 in r3_moves
17    assert r3_6 in r3_moves
18
19    # Face c1, c5, c2 has 2 possible R3 moves
20    r3_7 = {'stationary_crossing': 'c1',
21            'stationary_edge_1': 'e4',
22            'stationary_edge_2': 'e1',
23            'moving_crossing_1': 'c5',
24            'moving_crossing_2': 'c2',
25            'moving_edge': 'e5'}
26
27    r3_3 = {'stationary_crossing': 'c2',
28            'stationary_edge_1': 'e1',
29            'stationary_edge_2': 'e5',
30            'moving_crossing_1': 'c1',
31            'moving_crossing_2': 'c5',
32            'moving_edge': 'e4'}
33
34    assert r3_7 in r3_moves
35    assert r3_3 in r3_moves
36
37def test_apply_r3(two_unknots_1, two_unknots_2, poly_two_unknots):
38
39    sgd = two_unknots_1
40
41    assert sgd.yamada_polynomial() == poly_two_unknots
42
43    # Hardcoded R3 move
44    r3_3 = {'stationary_crossing': 'c1',
45            'stationary_edge_1': 'e2',
46            'stationary_edge_2': 'e3',
47            'moving_crossing_1': 'c3',
48            'moving_crossing_2': 'c4',
49            'moving_edge': 'e7'}
50
51    sgd_post_r3 = apply_r3_move(sgd, r3_3)
52

Now we will perform the test

Example Test Function¶
 1
 2    r3_moves = available_r3_moves(sgd_post_r3)
 3    assert len(r3_moves) == 8
 4
 5
 6def test_reverse_r3(two_unknots_1, poly_two_unknots):
 7
 8    sgd = two_unknots_1
 9
10    assert sgd.yamada_polynomial() == poly_two_unknots
11
12    r3_moves = available_r3_moves(sgd)
13    assert len(r3_moves) > 0
14
15    r3 = {'stationary_crossing': 'c1',
16            'stationary_edge_1': 'e2',
17            'stationary_edge_2': 'e3',
18            'moving_crossing_1': 'c3',
19            'moving_crossing_2': 'c4',
20            'moving_edge': 'e7'}
21
22    sgd_post_r3 = apply_r3_move(sgd, r3)
23
24    assert sgd_post_r3.yamada_polynomial() == poly_two_unknots
25
26    r3_rev = {'stationary_crossing': 'c1',
27              'stationary_edge_1': 'e3',
28              'stationary_edge_2': 'e2',
29              'moving_crossing_1': 'c4',
30              'moving_crossing_2': 'c3',
31              'moving_edge': 'e7'}
32
33    sgd_post_rev_r3 = apply_r3_move(sgd_post_r3, r3_rev)
34
